- [Cris] On this edition

5.21.text:
we explore the link

Can hearing favorite

Funding for The Best

43.84.text: Striving to do the greatest good

45.95.text:
by helping the greatest

65.10.text:
Welcome to this edition
of The Best Times.

67.57.text:
A series that looks
at life after 50.

71.14.text:
The man who was known as
the world's oldest teenager,

76.01.text:
"Music is the soundtrack
of your life."

79.71.text:
We associate songs with
events in our lives.

83.12.text:
It only takes a
few bars of music

85.39.text:
to take you back to
a time or a place

88.32.text: to remember a friend or a lover.

90.96.text:
Those memories are
etched in our minds

93.29.text:
and the music acts as a
trigger to bring them out.

96.40.text:
In recent years,
scientists and researchers

98.80.text:
have discovered that
music can trigger memories

101.37.text:
in patients with
Alzheimer's or dementia.

104.50.text:
A digital music player
and a pair of headphones

107.31.text:
can play the soundtrack
of their lives too.

110.11.text: And the results can be amazing.

113.05.text:
Tonight on The Best
Times we examine the link

133.70.text:
Miss Velma Haynes is
being wheeled into

135.80.text:
the multi-sensory room
at Signature Healthcare.

144.78.text:
The result of a fall that caused
a hemorrhage in her brain.

149.35.text:
Like most dementia
patients she seems

154.22.text:
But watch as Reverend
Tom Davis places

158.69.text:
The sound of her
favorite gospel hymns

160.69.text:
seems to act like a switch
that turns on her brain,

165.07.text:
and soon Velma is singing
quietly to the music

170.87.text:
- That's the whole point of
the music and memory program

176.34.text:
those songs that
have been with her

180.41.text: in different parts of her life

181.88.text:
that somehow gets rooted
in those cells of the brain

185.89.text:
becomes a part of who
she is, or who you are,

189.12.text:
and the music kind
of brings that out.

192.53.text:
Brings you back to kind
of a sense of identity.

196.96.text: That's what I see with her.

201.44.text:
Those hymns ground her
as a person of faith.

208.41.text:
She's witnessed first-hand
the positive impact

211.18.text: of music therapy on her mother.

216.72.text: When I come in in the evening,

218.49.text:
I usually come mostly every
afternoon at dinner time,

221.86.text:
and when I come
in she tells me--

224.06.text:
I asked her, "Did
you sing today?"

226.03.text:
She said, "Yeah we sung.
We had a great time."

229.03.text:
Her movement, I think it keeps
her body a little bit more

233.67.text:
flexible and limber
because she does move.

237.20.text:
- [Tom] What I love
about her is her humor.

242.34.text:
And I just think
that's wonderful to be

249.42.text:
She finds humor in
things and I just think

254.52.text:
I see that being able to
come out through the music

257.09.text:
but I don't think the
music has made her that way

259.79.text:
I just think it helps
release who she is.

262.66.text:
- [Cris] Gospel music is the
soundtrack of Velma's life.

266.17.text:
But what is the source
of music's magic?

269.17.text:
It turns out that the
parts of the brain

271.17.text:
that respond to
music are very close

274.27.text:
to the brain's memory
and mood centers.

277.41.text:
- What we have
left is the senses

280.21.text: if the brain is not functioning.

283.08.text:
Whether it's sight or taste
or smell, hearing, touch.

288.72.text:
Those senses kind of helps a
person get connected again.

295.36.text:
How old were you when you
started going to church?

308.68.text:
Do you have any
brothers and sisters?

327.13.text:
You want to listen

330.43.text:
Alright let's see

333.47.text:
What really has come
through with Miss Velma

337.67.text:
is that connection
to her grandmother.

347.85.text:
Music helps bring you
back to that sense

350.12.text: of love for people of the past.

353.95.text:
Just that need to
connect is a hunger,

358.86.text:
and I think the music kind
of helps a person reconnect.

364.36.text:
Not just opening
up to other people

but reconnect to those

369.80.text: that you experience as a person.

372.14.text:
I really go back
to that sense of

379.88.text:
As long as something
musical or whatever

383.05.text:
can keep you moving and

392.29.text:
- We all know the
power of music.

394.59.text:
Just hearing a
song from your past

396.83.text:
can bring forth a flood
of memories and emotions.

But scientists and

403.04.text: to understand why and how music

405.67.text:
can benefit Alzheimer's

409.21.text:
To find out more about the
link between music and memory

I've invited three
guests into the studio.

Deborah Ferris is regional

420.79.text:
that trains professional

in internal medicine at

director of spirituality at

440.14.text:
I think what we saw with
Velma to me it was amazing

442.88.text:
because it was almost
like a door was opening.

I don't know whether that's

to know stories

452.19.text:
Other instances that
you may have seen.

How does she compare

458.06.text:
- I guess one that always
comes to mind for me

467.53.text:
and she was in community
based care for the last

473.17.text:
Her body was really taken
over by Parkinson's,

477.14.text:
and hers was the first
personalized music

480.71.text:
playlist that I ever
designed as a volunteer.

484.85.text:
We worked with her sister and
created a playlist for her

494.86.text:
and all the music that she
listened to when she was young

497.43.text: on American Bandstand and so on.

500.40.text:
Sylvia had been non-verbal
for a number of years.

504.47.text:
She really had, I guess you
could say, a blank stare.

512.05.text:
So when we began to give
her access to her music

515.78.text: the playlist that we had created

518.72.text:
the first thing that
we noticed was that

520.35.text:
she began to make eye
contact with her sister

525.13.text:
that the care staff
would arrange each week.

529.10.text:
The second thing that we
noticed was that she began

531.90.text:
to speak and respond
to her sister

535.37.text:
after, as I said,
years of silence.

538.51.text:
She ultimately began
to speak with her nurse

542.38.text: which was shocking for her nurse

544.54.text: and the nurse at first said,

545.98.text:
"Well that's just not
possible, she's non-verbal,

548.11.text:
"she's been in my
care for years."

555.99.text:
how many times a day she
needed access to her music

558.93.text:
and for how long and
things of that nature.

561.86.text:
So they would give her
access several times

564.80.text:
throughout the day before
meals to stimulate her

569.44.text:
and she did gain
weight as a result.

571.84.text:
And then also first thing
in the morning before her

575.01.text:
dressing and bathing and
activities of daily living,

579.01.text:
and what happened was that
Sylvia would relax after

583.32.text:
she had listened to

585.85.text:
and then it was
no longer painful

591.32.text:
that she was able
to not only reduce

593.56.text:
but completely eliminate
Sylvia's pain medications.

601.13.text:
And of course the sister
was just so profoundly moved

604.17.text:
that she said, "Thank you,
it's like I have my sister

608.61.text:
"back again. And I know
nothing will cure her,

612.38.text:
"but the music
brings her great joy,

614.65.text:
"and it's really the only
thing she can participate in."

617.75.text:
She was very happy to have
that in her final years.

you used the word

Even though she may

and we kind of

- Well I'm curious about the
science behind all of this.

From your description and

696.20.text: what I've seen in other cases,

702.27.text:
- Simply put, the music
centers of the brain

are closely aligned with the

708.61.text:
It's one of that last

711.24.text:
to be harmed by

You were asking earlier

My first awareness of

726.03.text:
was seeing patients who

729.20.text:
that impaired their

731.56.text:
they knew what

733.60.text: but the words wouldn't come out.

735.64.text:
Scientifically we call
than an expressive aphasia.

740.17.text:
When you sing the lyrics,
the words come out.

744.28.text:
I guess you could
say that's magical.

746.18.text: I like to think of it as magical

747.81.text:
because I think the body is
much more than what we can

750.88.text:
actually look at under
a microscope or measure.

755.96.text: We have so much more there

759.19.text:
and to reduce it
completely to a science

762.90.text:
I think is unfair to the
brain in a lot of aspects.

769.67.text:
- What kind of communication
would you call it?

is I see that there's an

786.39.text:
that goes beyond anything

It connects the part of the

794.79.text:
and interprets these
kinds of things

and connects them in a way with

with people that they may

May not, as you say, be

For our kind of quality of

Sometimes, some of

because they're startled,

It's very endearing,

and the participant

and really changes that

926.96.text:

So what we've always

it's really not possible

for an individual,

So it's usually based on

What Music and Memory

a new best practice in the care

and using eras and

962.26.text:
the initial stepping stones

of an autobiographical

And what we've discovered

greater benefits live, and

But I think it's

984.58.text:
So it's very person centered,

for as long as they need

and that's determined

But it has to be the

meaning for them to take

of engagement and community

- [Tom] I think that's--

That's part of when we

So we kind of try

1023.89.text: but when we have several songs

and a family member

and so you've got two

and then what comes out

So it becomes kind of

1050.85.text:
of mom or dad or sister,

maybe for the first

You mentioned, for

I think it's fascinating

about specific playlists and

to maybe even 20 or 30 of

1095.70.text:
in an emotional time

1097.90.text:
and it's almost like this is

And then there's another

1106.61.text:
that are maybe the
20 milligram dosage

1110.11.text:
without all the side-effects,
and without any side-effects

1113.85.text:
other than a better connection

1119.45.text:
It's fascinating when you

1121.69.text:
because the problem we've

for a long time is we have

We don't have any

So we're left with

No good choices

1143.21.text: What a great choice this is.

organization, Music and Memory

1148.18.text:
because you actually train

when individuals are

when you begin to try and

1177.81.text:
to many individuals in a

you really need some

The staff really doesn't have

So what we provide is

1204.74.text:
Although, the program

1211.64.text:
into every type of

So we train those

that care organization to

1223.92.text:
- Now, is this something the
family caregivers can do?

1230.33.text:
I want to make sure
everyone knows too that

1237.30.text:
there are publications and
resources that can help

1239.97.text:
these family caregivers at
home that are free to them

1242.71.text:
that they can
download and access

1245.28.text:
because caregiving is such a
challenge, it's high stress.

1250.88.text:
Sometimes these family
members have been

1252.72.text:
on a really long journey
with their loved one.

1255.29.text:
Especially when you're looking
at dementia and Alzheimer's

1259.02.text:
specifically, and they just
kind of run out of options,

1264.80.text:
and they really are in

1267.67.text:
and some tools that they

1273.11.text:
There is something, there's

1276.01.text:
that can make-- for example
you can have several playlists

1281.98.text:
on one little iPod a little

1288.02.text:
And let's say that we

1291.42.text:
for mom or dad, so instead of

their resting playlist

We can also have another

to cause them to be

1323.62.text: We also have a lot of caregivers

When I say that I

let's say that dad

and go to his

- I'm curious as to where

I think this is one of the

Dementia patients in nursing

1382.35.text:
of our society that

1402.33.text:
I just think it has

And I think when you start

1407.57.text:

all these kids now

1414.71.text:

To me, I'm not smart enough

but I know that there's
an application here

1424.99.text:
many applications that
spans many levels of care

1429.43.text:

Any medical arena

and any disease that

I'm not saying it's

who have a high incidence

this would be a great

I think the dementia aspect

and we need as a country

1474.51.text: I think we will because it works

and I think the powers

Other parts of the

1498.63.text:
